prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3C124
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mapping the dust continuum in the host of 3C124.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We propose for purely continuum (correlator in TDM with maximum effective bandwidth of 7.5 GHz), spatially resolved (0.3 arcsec angular resolution) observations at Band 7, to study the continuum emission at rest-frame wavelengths of ~400 microns. Based on our SED decomposition method (see Figure 1), we estimate a thermal continuum flux density of ~1.5 mJy at this wavelength. To obtain an image with a reasonable dynamic range and an excellent astrometric accuracy, we aim to obtain a S/N ~ 30, therefore we set the sensitivity to 0.05 mJy/beam. The representative frequency chosen is the one which minimizes the total time estimate, which based on the Sensitivity Calculator is ~55 minutes (including time needed for calibrations and overheads). Our source target measures just a few arcsec, hence no additional configurations or ACA are needed. It fully fits within 1/3 of the primary beam, ensuring uniform sensitivity within the source. No scheduling constraints are associated with this Science Goal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3C190 and 3C191
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mapping the dust continuum in the hosts of 3C190 and 3C191.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We propose for purely continuum (correlator in TDM with maximum effective bandwidth of 7.5 GHz), spatially resolved (0.3 arcsec angular resolution) observations at Band 6, to study the continuum emission at rest-frame wavelengths of ~400-500 microns for two targets. Two individual pointings are requested to image the two targets, separated by ~4 deg on the sky. Based on our SED decomposition method (see Figure 1), we estimate a thermal continuum flux density (for the weakest component) of ~1 mJy at these wavelengths. To obtain an image with a reasonable dynamic range and an excellent astrometric accuracy, we aim to obtain a S/N ~ 20, therefore we set the sensitivity to 0.05 mJy/beam. The representative frequency chosen is the one which minimizes the total time estimate, which based on the Sensitivity Calculator is ~44 minutes (including time needed for calibrations and overheads). The excellent observing conditions at Band 6 (~7 minutes on-source time per target), translate in overheads of ~32% of the total requested time (the exact same setup in Band 7 requires twice as much time). Our source targets measure just a few arcsec, hence no additional configurations or ACA are needed. Both targets fully fit within 1/3 of the primary beam, ensuring uniform sensitivity within the sources. No scheduling constraints are associated with this Science Goal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3C257
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mapping the dust continuum in the host of 3C257.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We propose for purely continuum (correlator in TDM with maximum effective bandwidth of 7.5 GHz), spatially resolved (0.3 arcsec angular resolution) observations at Band 6, to study the continuum emission at rest-frame wavelengths of ~400 microns. Based on our SED decomposition method (see Figure 1), we estimate a thermal continuum flux density of ~2 mJy at this wavelength. To obtain an image with a reasonable dynamic range and an excellent astrometric accuracy, we aim to obtain a S/N ~ 40, therefore we set the sensitivity to 0.05 mJy/beam. The representative frequency chosen is the one which minimizes the total time estimate, which based on the Sensitivity Calculator is ~34 minutes (including time needed for calibrations and overheads). The excellent observing conditions at Band 6 (7 minutes on-source time), translate in overheads of ~38% of the total requested time (the exact same setup in Band 7 requires almost 50% more time). Our source target measures just a few arcsec, hence no additional configurations or ACA are needed. It fully fits within 1/3 of the primary beam, ensuring uniform sensitivity within the source. No scheduling constraints are associated with this Science Goal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3C298
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mapping the dust continuum in the host of 3C257.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We propose for purely continuum (correlator in TDM with maximum effective bandwidth of 7.5 GHz), spatially resolved (0.3 arcsec angular resolution) observations at Band 7, to study the continuum emission at rest-frame wavelengths of ~400 microns. Based on our SED decomposition method (see Figure 1), we estimate a thermal continuum flux density of ~5 mJy at this wavelength. To obtain an image with a reasonable dynamic range and an excellent astrometric accuracy, we aim to obtain a S/N ~ 50, therefore we set the sensitivity to 0.1 mJy/beam. The representative frequency chosen is the one which minimizes the total time estimate, which based on the Sensitivity Calculator is ~33 minutes (including time needed for calibrations and overheads). Our source target measures just a few arcsec, hence no additional configurations or ACA are needed. It fully fits within 1/3 of the primary beam, ensuring uniform sensitivity within the source. No scheduling constraints are associated with this Science Goal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3C368
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mapping the dust continuum in the host of 3C257.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We propose for purely continuum (correlator in TDM with maximum effective bandwidth of 7.5 GHz), spatially resolved (0.3 arcsec angular resolution) observations at Band 7, to study the continuum emission at rest-frame wavelengths of ~400 microns. Based on our SED decomposition method (see Figure 1), we estimate a thermal continuum flux density of ~1.5 mJy at this wavelength. To obtain an image with a reasonable dynamic range and an excellent astrometric accuracy, we aim to obtain a S/N ~ 30, therefore we set the sensitivity to 0.05 mJy/beam. The representative frequency chosen is the one which minimizes the total time estimate, which based on the Sensitivity Calculator is ~56 minutes (including time needed for calibrations and overheads). Our source target measures just a few arcsec, hence no additional configurations or ACA are needed. It fully fits within 1/3 of the primary beam, ensuring uniform sensitivity within the source. No scheduling constraints are associated with this Science Goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Kpc-scale resolution ALMA imaging of restframe 400 micron dust emission in the prodigiously star-forming hosts of six high redshift 3C radio sources is requested. The resulting images will permit spatial separation of the AGN vs. star-formation heated dust, will yield reliable star-formation rates, and will permit assessment of positive/negative feedback effects. The questions to be answered are: what is the star-formation rate of ultramassive early epoch galaxies during an ultraluminous black hole accretion (=AGN) episode? where does the star-formation take place in the host? is it jet-induced or jet-quenched? can SFRs be simply inferred from SED decomposition? -- all of prime importance in extragalactic astrophysics.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen
